SourceText: Ouma means grandmother. Do you have favorite names for people you are close to?
text: 「オウマ」とは祖母を意味します。 親しい人のお気に入りの名前はありますか?

SourceText: The people and the seagulls want the same things for dinner -- maybe a yellowtail or a crab. How many different kinds of fish do you know?
text: 人々もカモメも夕食に同じものを望んでいますーブリかカニかもしれません。 あなたは何種類の魚を知っていますか?

SourceText: A rectangle is a shape with four straight sides like this page. The doors and roofs of the buildings are rectangles. How many rectangles do you see in this picture? How many rectangles do you see where you are?
text: 長方形とは、このページのように 4 つの直線の辺がある形状です。 建物のドアや屋根は長方形です。 この絵の中に長方形が何個見えますか? 自分のいる場所に長方形が何個見えますか?

SourceText: Last year the fishermen fought with the surfers. Angry fists and shouting words. "Whaaat? Whaaat? Whaaat?" cried the gulls. "There's enough sea for everybody," said Yusuf's father. He showed them the fishing license that had been Oupa Salie's. "Waves for all. Water for free."
text: 去年、漁師はサーファーと争った。 怒りの拳と叫び声。 「えっ？ えっ？ えっ？」 カモメたちが叫びました。 「誰にとっても海は十分にある」とユスフさんの父親は語った。 彼は彼らにオウパ・サリーのものだった漁業許可証を見せた。 「波はみんなに。水は無料。」

SourceText: What were the fishermen and surfers arguing about? What bad things might happen if they are in the same place?
text: 漁師とサーファーは何について議論していましたか? 同じ場所にいるとどんな悪いことが起こるでしょうか？

SourceText: People have disagreements, and then they find ways to resolve them. Think of a disagreement you had with someone. How did you solve that problem?
text: 人々は意見の相違があると、それを解決する方法を見つけます。 誰かと意見の相違があったことを思い出してください。 その問題をどうやって解決しましたか?

SourceText: What feelings do you have when you get into an argument with someone?
text: 誰かと口論になったとき、あなたはどんな気持ちになりますか?

SourceText: Ouma Safiya watches through her binoculars, her fingers curled in curiosity. The shark siren sounds. Swimmers run back to the sand and grab their towels. Surfers rush to the shore, carrying their boards under their arms. Under the showers they strip off their wetsuits. "Whaaat? Whaaat? Whaaat?" cry the gulls. "What will Yusuf's father bring from the ocean?"
text: オウマ・サフィヤは双眼鏡を覗き込み、好奇心で指を丸めている。サメの声が聞こえる。 泳ぐ人たちは砂浜に走って戻り、タオルを掴みます。 サーファーたちはボードを小脇に抱えて海岸に急ぐ。 シャワーの下で彼らはウェットスーツを脱ぎます。 「えっ？ えっ？ えっ？」 カモメが鳴きます。 「ユスフのお父さんは海から何を持ってくるでしょうか？」

SourceText: There are hundreds of kinds of sharks in the world. Here are a few of those kinds: Great White Shark, Tiger Shark, Hammerhead Shark, Lemon Shark, and Nurse Shark.
text: 世界には何百種類ものサメがいます。 ホホジロザメ、イタチザメ、シュモクザメ、レモンシャーク、ナースシャークなど、その種類をいくつか紹介します。

SourceText: Some sharks are dangerous. Others have no interest in people, such as nurse sharks. A leopard shark has never attacked a person and they just hunt for crabs.
text: サメの中には危険なものもいます。 ナースザメのように、人間に興味を持たないサメもいます。 ヒョウモンザメは人を襲ったことはなく、カニを狙っているだけです。

SourceText: Goblin sharks are not very aggressive. They have not attacked a person, partly because they are so far out in the deep ocean.
text: ゴブリンシャークはあまり攻撃的ではありません。 彼らは深海に遠く離れていることもあり、人を襲ったことはありません。

SourceText: Yusuf's father and uncle and cousins heave and pull. A little shark has been caught. Yusuf's father untangles the nets, singing to the shark: "Drop and swish. Find a fish. Pull and plop. Don't you stop." When the shark at last is free it streaks back into the waves, leaving only one fat yellowtail in the net. Ouma Safiya will be pleased.
text: ユセフの父親、叔父、いとこたちは、引っ張り合いをしている。小さなサメが捕獲されました。 ユスフの父親は網をほどき、サメに向かって「落として、振り回して。魚を見つけて。ひっぱって、ポチャン。止まらないで。」と歌いました。 ようやくサメが自由になると、網の中に太ったブリ一匹だけを残して波の中に戻っていきます。 オウマ・サフィヤもきっと喜ぶだろう。

SourceText: Why does Yusuf's father let the little shark go free?
text: ユスフの父親はなぜ小さなサメを放したのですか?

SourceText: The fin in the shape of a triangle on a shark's back is called a dorsal fin. It helps keep the shark upright in the water and it also helps it make quick turns.
text: サメの背中にある三角形のヒレを背鰭といいます。 これはサメを水中で直立状態に保つのに役立ち、素早い方向転換にも役立ちます。

SourceText: The net in the picture has circular objects shaped like donuts on its edge. They're not donuts! What do you think they are for?
text: 写真のネットの端にドーナツのような丸い物体が付いています。 ドーナツじゃないよ！ それらは何のためにあると思いますか?

SourceText: The men pull the boat in and coil up the cables. A hard white triangle catches Papa's finger. "Whaaat? Whaaat" Whaaat?" cry the gulls. "What did you bring back for Yusuf?" As the sun goes down, Papa answers the gulls. "A lucky shark tooth for my boy." At home Yusuf holds his gift up to the stars.
text: 男たちはボートを引き込み、ケーブルを巻きます。 固い白い三角がパパの指を引っ掛ける。 「えっ？えっ？えっ？」とカモメが叫びます。「ユスフに何を持って帰ったの？」日が落ちるとパパがカモメに答えます。「息子に幸運のサメの歯を」家でユスフは贈り物を星々へかざす 。

SourceText: The shark's tooth is a hard, white triangle. Do you remember another triangle on the shark's body? Do you see any triangles around you now?
text: サメの歯は白くて硬い三角形です。 サメの体にもう一つ三角形があるのを覚えていますか? 今あなたの周りに三角形があるのが見えますか？

SourceText: Do you remember what some of the other gifts were from earlier in the story?
text: 物語の前半で他の贈り物が何だったか覚えていますか?

SourceText: Do you have special things you've found that you like to keep? Perhaps you found a pretty rock or a bird's feather that you liked a lot?
text: 取っておきたい特別なものはありますか? とても気に入ったきれいな石や鳥の羽を見つけたのではないでしょうか?

SourceText: Once upon a time on a little farm near a little village.
text: むかしむかし小さな村の近くに小さな農場がありました。

SourceText: Farms can grow crops and raise animals, such as chickens. What are some things on a farm that you are curious about?
text: 農場は作物を育てたり、ニワトリなどの動物たちを育てることができるよ。農場にある不思議だなって思うものたちは何かな？

SourceText: There are some groups of three things here. What do you see?
text: ここには３つのものがあるよ。 何が見えるかな？

SourceText: What are the different things these chickens are doing?
text: ニワトリたちはそれぞれ何をしているのかな？

SourceText: There lived a little chicken called Daisy.
text: そこにはデイジーという名前の小さなニワトリが住んでいました。

SourceText: Count together the claws that Daisy has on each leg and all together.
text: デイジーのそれぞれの足にある爪を一緒に数えてみよう。

SourceText: Daisy's claws spread out to help her balance. How long can you balance on one leg?
text: デイジーの爪はバランスを取れるようにするために分かれているんだよ。君は１本の足だけでどれくらいバランスが取れるかな？

SourceText: Can you balance on one leg long enough to count to five? To ten?
text: ５つ数えられるくらいバランスを取れるかな？それとも１０？

SourceText: "When I grow up, I want to fly high, high into the sky," Daisy said.
text: 「大きくなったら、高く、お空に届くくらい高く飛びたい。」デイジーは言いました。

SourceText: Count together all the circles on their faces. Don't forget to count the pupils in the middle of the eyes.
text: ニワトリたちの顔の中にある丸を一緒に数えよう。 目の中にある黒目も忘れちゃダメだよ。

SourceText: How can you tell that the other chickens are not as happy as Daisy?
text: デイジー以外のニワトリたちはどうしてそんなに幸せそうじゃないのかな？

SourceText: What are these other chicken's thinking?
text: 他のニワトリたちは何を考えているんだろう？

SourceText: But all the other chickens laughed at her.
text: けれど、他のニワトリたちはデイジーを笑いました。

SourceText: Their eyes are now closed. We close our eyes when we are asleep and at other times. Why are these chicken's eyes closed?
text: ニワトリたちの目は閉じているよ。みんなは寝る時とかに目を閉じるよね。なんでニワトリたちは目を閉じているんだろう？

SourceText: Sometimes people laugh AT other people, and sometimes they laugh WITH other people. What is the difference?
text: 人は他の人を見て笑う時もあれば、他の人と一緒に笑う時もあるよね。その違いはなんだろう？

SourceText: Do you think the shape of the big cloud looks like their mouths?
text: 大きな雲の形はニワトリたちの口みたいだと思う？

SourceText: "You are so weird," they said. "We won't play with you anymore."
text: 「デイジーは変だよ。」他のニワトリは言いました。「もうデイジーとは遊ばない。」

SourceText: Now that their mouths have changed, do you think the cloud changed shape too?
text: ニワトリたちの口が変わったね。雲の形も変わったと思うかな？

SourceText: Can you use your mouth to copy the shape of each chicken's mouth? Can you guess and copy the sound each chicken is making?
text: それぞれのニワトリたちの口の形を真似できる？どんな音を出しているかな？

SourceText: Why are they calling Daisy a mean name?
text: どうしてニワトリたちはデイジーのことを意地悪な名前でよんでいるんだろう？

SourceText: "Daisy, we can all flap our wings, but it's very difficult for chickens to fly," Mama told her.
text: 「デイジー、羽根を羽ばたかせることはできても、ニワトリにとって飛ぶことはすごく難しいんだよ。」ママは言いました。

SourceText: Discuss what is similar about Daisy and her mother, and how they look different from the other chickens.
text: デイジーとデイジーのお母さんのどこが似ているのか、どこが他のニワトリたちと違うのか、話し合ってみよう。

SourceText: What is Daisy's mother doing to help Daisy feel better?
text: デイジーのお母さんはデイジーの気分を良くしてあげるために何をしているのかな？

SourceText: Sometimes we feel better when someone pats us or holds our hand. Have you ever tried to help a friend feel better with a friendly touch?
text: ときどき誰かが撫でてくれたり手を握ってくれたりすると気分が良くなるよね。君は今までそんな風にお友達の気分を良くしてあげたことあるかな？

SourceText: Daisy wouldn't give up. Every day she practiced by herself, flapping her wings. Flap, flap, flap, she would flap her wings but she couldn't lift off the ground.
text: デイジーは諦めませんでした。毎日１人で練習をして、羽をパタパタと動かし続けました。パタパタ、パタパタ、パタパタ、羽を羽ばたかしても地面から上がることはできませんでした。

SourceText: So far, this is a sad story for Daisy. Make up your own ending. Is it a happy or sad ending?
text: ここまではデイジーにとって悲しいお話だよね。君だけのエンディングを作ってみよう。幸せな終わり方かな？それとも悲しい終わり方かな？

SourceText: Is Daisy too heavy to fly? Think of something that is as heavy as Daisy looks. Do you think that thing is too heavy to fly?
text: デイジーが飛ぶには重すぎるのかな？デイジーと同じくらいの重さのものを考えてみよう。それは飛ぶには重すぎると思う？

SourceText: A rectangle is a shape with four straight sides and corners like the corners of this page. Although they are slanted, find and point to the many rectangles on this page.
text: 長方形とは、このページの角みたいに、4 つの直線の辺と角を持つ形のことだよ。傾いているけど、このページにあるたくさんの長方形を探して見つけてみよう。

SourceText: While she practiced, she imagined herself flying high into the sky and looking at the chickens below. She imagined herself flying past the sparrows and past the swallows. "Wow!" The birds would say, "A chicken that can fly!"
text: 練習をしながらデイジーは自分が空高く飛んで下にいるニワトリたちを見ている姿を想像しました。スズメやツバメの横を飛んでいる自分の姿を想像しました。「わーお！」トリたちは言います。「ニワトリが飛んでるよ！」

SourceText: Count together the birds in this picture. Don't forget the ones on the ground.
text: 絵の中にいるトリを一緒に数えてみよう。地面にいる子も忘れないでね。

SourceText: What effect is caused by having some of the birds drawn so small?
text: すごく小さく描かれたトリたちがいることでどんな効果があるかな？

SourceText: Describe a memory of looking at something big that was far away and looked tiny.
text: 何か大きいものだけど遠くにあって小さく見えるものを見た記憶を説明してみよう。

SourceText: So flap, flap, flap, every day Daisy would flap her wings.
text: なので、パタパタ、パタパタ、パタパタ、とデイジーは毎日羽を羽ばたかせていました。

SourceText: Count together the little lines coming from Daisy showing her squawking.
text: デイジーがガアガア鳴いているところから来ている小さな線を一緒に数えてみよう。

SourceText: Daisy has too many red speckles to count, but you can count together the groups of speckles all over her body.
text: デイジーには数えるには多すぎるくらいたくさんの赤い斑点があるね。だけどデイジーの体にある赤い斑点のグループは一緒に数えられるよ。

SourceText: Daisy looks surprised. What do you think will happen next?
text: デイジーは驚いてるみたいだね。次は何が起こると思う？

SourceText: She would lift off the ground but fall down again.
text: デイジーは地面から上がってもまた落ちてしまいました。

SourceText: How high do you think she got? A grownup is often 5 to 6 feet tall -- do you think she got that high?
text: デイジーはどのくらいの高さまで飛べたと思う？大人の身長は大体150cmから180cmだよ。デイジーはそれくらいの高さまで飛べたと思う？

SourceText: How many lines are there above her and below her? When you combine them, how many are there in all?
text: デイジーの上と下には何本の線があるかな？それを全部合わせてみると何本になる？

SourceText: What do the lines below her show?
text: デイジーの下にある線は何を表してるかな？

SourceText: "I'm never going to fly!" Daisy cried to Mama. "The others are right."
text: 「絶対に飛べないよ。」デイジーは泣いてママに言いました。「他のニワトリたちが正しかったんだ。」

SourceText: Describe some times when you got discouraged like Daisy.
text: 君がデイジーみたいにがっかりした時のことを説明してみよう。

SourceText: Daisy is trying the same thing over and over. Is she showing strong will or is she being stubbornly foolish?
text: デイジーは同じことを何回も何回も試しているよね。デイジーは強い意志を表しているのかな？それとも頑固で愚かな姿になっているのかな？

SourceText: What new ideas might Daisy try to figure out how to fly?
text: デイジーが飛び方を見つけるためにどんな新しいアイデアが試せるかな？

SourceText: "Daisy, you are different from the other chickens. They don't want to fly but you do! You can do it." Mama said.
text: 「デイジー、あなたは他のニワトリたちとは違うんだよ。他のみんなは飛びたがらないけどあなたは違う！デイジーならできるよ！」ママは言いました。

SourceText: How can you tell from Daisy's face that she is getting a new idea?
text: デイジーに新しいアイデアが浮かんできたということがデイジーの顔からどうやってわかるかな？

SourceText: Think of a problem you solved by coming up with a new way to do it after the old way kept failing.
text: 古い方法が失敗し続けた後、新しい方法を考え出すことで解決できた問題を考えてみよう。

SourceText: Daisy's body is made up of pairs of things, such as her eyes, and single things, such as her tail. Name all the pairs you can and then all the singles you can.
text: デイジーの体は目などのペアと、尻尾などの単体のもので作られているよ。できる限り全部のペアと単体のものに名前をつけてみよう。

SourceText: The following day Daisy climbed to the top of the chicken coop and flap, flap, flap, she flapped her wings. She flew into the air and flapped her wings and flapped her wings and flapped her wings and ...
text: 次の日、デイジーは鶏小屋のてっぺんまで登ってパタパタ、パタパタ、パタパタ、と羽を羽ばたかせました。デイジーは空に飛んで羽をパタパタと羽ばたかせました、、、

SourceText: There are lots of straight lines here. Some are vertical -- they go up and down. Some are horizontal -- they go side to side. Find some vertical and horizontal lines where you are.
text: ここにはたくさんの直線があるね。いくつかは垂直な線で、上下の縦に動くよ。いくつかは水平な線で、左右の横に動くよ。君のいる場所にある垂直な線と水平な線を探そう。

SourceText: What do the curved lines next to Daisy's body indicate?
text: デイジーの体の横にある曲線は何を示しているかな？

SourceText: Daisy's face is very expressive. What does her face show this time?
text: デイジーは表情が豊かだね。この時のデイジーの顔は何を表しているかな？

SourceText: BAM!
text: バン！

SourceText: How is Daisy feeling right now?
text: デイジーの今の気分はどうですか？

SourceText: What is the other chicken doing?
text: 他のニワトリたちは何をしていますか？

SourceText: A kind and thoughtful chicken might go over and console and cheer Daisy up. Why isn't this chicken doing that?
text: 親切で思いやりのあるニワトリならデイジーのところへ行って慰めたり元気付けたりするかもしれないよね。けれど、なんでこのニワトリはそうしなかったのかな？

SourceText: The other chickens laughed out loud. "Ha ha ha! We told you! Chickens can't fly!"
text: 他のニワトリたちは大きな声で笑いました。「ハッハッハ！言った通りだ！ニワトリは飛べないよ！」

SourceText: There is one thick vertical line in this picture. Do you see any other vertical or horizontal lines?
text: この絵の中に太い垂直線があるよ。他に垂直線や平行線は見える？

SourceText: Is the laughing chicken walking or running? How can you tell?
text: 笑っているニワトリは歩いてる？走ってる？どうしてわかるのかな？

SourceText: Do you think Daisy will give up after this bad fall? When you have a failure, is it hard for you to keep trying?
text: この悪い失敗のあとデイジーは諦めてしまうかな？君が何か失敗をした時、努力し続けるのは難しい？

SourceText: But the next day Daisy climbed even higher, right up to the top of the hut. Flap, flap, flap, Daisy flapped her wings.
text: けれど、次の日、デイジーはさらに高く登り、小屋のてっぺんまで登りました。パタパタ、パタパタ、デイジーが羽ばたきました。

SourceText: Daisy is determined. Can you think of a time when you kept trying even after several failures?
text: デイジーは決意しました。君は何回も失敗しても挑戦し続けたことあるかな？

SourceText: Daisy is trying to solve her problem. What have been some of her new ideas for this problem?
text: デイジーは自分の問題を解決しようとしているよ。デイジーの問題のための新しいアイデアはどんなものだったかな？

SourceText: Why did they show Daisy twice in this picture? Why does Daisy look big and the other chickens look so small?
text: なんでこの絵の中で２つのデイジーが描かれているのだろう？どうしてデイジーは大きくて他のニワトリたちはすごく小さいのだろう？

SourceText: She flew into the air and flapped her wings and flapped her wings and flapped her wings and ...
text: デイジーは空に飛び、羽ばたき、また羽ばたいて、また羽ばたき、そして...

SourceText: At last, Daisy is successful! How does that make you feel? It feels good to share the successes of others.
text: ついにデイジーは成功したよ！どう思ったかな？他の人の成功を共有すると気分がいいよね。

SourceText: How can you tell from the drawing that she is flying upward?
text: デイジーが上向きに飛んでいることをこの絵からどうやってわかるかな？

SourceText: Look at the movement lines drawn around her body. How are the movement lines in this picture different from the ones on the last page?
text: デイジーの体の周りに描かれた動線を見てみよう。絵の中にあるそれらの動線は最後のページにあったものとどう違うのかな？

SourceText: She kept flying! The wind beneath her wings grew stronger and she flew higher and higher! The sparrows and the swallows said, "Amazing! A flying chicken!"
text: デイジーは飛び続けました！羽の下の風はどんどん強くなり、デイジーは高く、高くに飛びました！スズメとツバメは言いました。「すごい！ニワトリが飛んでる！」

SourceText: How does Daisy's flying body look different from the other birds in the sky?
text: デイジーの飛んでいる姿は空にいる他のトリたちとどう違うかな？

SourceText: How is Daisy feeling now that all of her hard work has paid off?
text: デイジーはこれまでの努力が報われて今どんな気持ちかな？

SourceText: What are the other chickens thinking now?
text: 他のニワトリたちは今何を考えているかな？

SourceText: And the other chickens wanted to be just like her.
text: そして、他のニワトリたちはデイジーのようになりたがっていました。

SourceText: Use your arms to copy the positions of the wings of these chickens.
text: 腕を使ってニワトリの羽の形を真似してみよう。

SourceText: What are these chickens feeling now that Daisy is successful?
text: デイジーが成功して他のニワトリたちは今どんな気持ちかな？

SourceText: Do you think the other chickens will learn to fly someday?
text: 他のニワトリたちもいつか飛び方を学ぶと思う？

SourceText: They said, "Oh Daisy, you're amazing!"
text: 他のニワトリたちは言いました。「デイジー、君はすごいよ！」

SourceText: What happens next in Daisy's story after this book?
text: この本の後のデイジーのお話では何が起こるかな？

SourceText: Have you ever wished that you could fly?
text: 君は飛べたらいいのにって思ったことある？

SourceText: Where would you go if you could fly? What would you like to look at if you could get way up in the sky above it?
text: もし飛ぶことができたら君はどこに行く？はるか上の空に行けたら何がみたい？

SourceText: Everyone knows that the elephant has a very long nose.
text: ゾウの鼻がとっても長いのは誰でも知っているね。

SourceText: Elephants live in many places in Africa and Asia. What are some things you know about elephants?
text: ゾウはアフリカとアジアに多く住んでいるよ。ゾウについて知っていることは何かな？

SourceText: Have you ever seen an elephant? If so, did it look like this?
text: ゾウを見たことはある？ この絵のゾウみたいだった？

SourceText: There are two patches of hair on this elephant. Do elephants actually have hair like this?
text: このゾウには、毛が生えているところが2か所あるね。本当のゾウにも、こんな毛が生えているのかな？

SourceText: But a long time ago, the elephant's nose was short and fat. Like a shoe in the middle of its face.
text: でもずっと昔、ゾウの鼻は短くて太かった。まるで、顔の真ん中にくつがあるみたいに。

SourceText: Elephants have 5 toes on each foot. How many toes in total? One way to figure this out is to skip count by 5's -- 5, 10, 15, 20.
text: ゾウはそれぞれのあしに5本の指があるよ。ぜんぶ合わせると何本の指になるかな？ 解き方の1つは、5、10、15、20というように5とびで数えることだね。

SourceText: Elephants have large ears and can hear sounds up to six miles away.
text: ゾウには大きな耳があって、6マイル (約9,66km) はなれたところの音まで聞こえるよ。

SourceText: Elephants also use their ears to keep cool.
text: ゾウの耳は体を冷やすのにも使われるんだ。

SourceText: One day a baby elephant was born. She was curious about everything. She had a question for every animal.
text: ある日、赤ちゃんゾウが生まれたよ。そのゾウは何でも知りたがった。どの動物にも聞きたいことがあったんだ。

SourceText: Even numbers are numbers that can be split evenly in two. Odd numbers can't. The elephant has 2 eyes, 2 ears, and four legs -- all even numbers.
text: 偶数は2つに均等にわけられる数だね。奇数はそのようにわけられないよ。ゾウには目が2つ、耳が2つ、足が4本あって、これらはすべて偶数だね。

SourceText: Find some things in this picture that there are an odd number of.
text: この絵の中で、数が奇数であるものを探してみよう。

SourceText: Notice that all the body parts that there are an odd number of are in the middle of the elephant's body.
text: ゾウの部位で奇数のものは、体や顔の真ん中にあることに注目してね。

SourceText: She was curious about Giraffe. "Why do you have a long neck?" she asked.
text: キリンについて知りたくなった。「どうして首が長いの？」と聞いたよ。

SourceText: Can you count the Giraffe's dark spots, or are there too many to count?
text: キリンの黒い模様を数えられる？ それとも数えるには多すぎる？

SourceText: No two giraffe's have the same pattern of dark spots!
text: どのキリンにもそれぞれ違った模様があるよ！

SourceText: Do you think it takes a giraffe a long time to swallow its food because it has such a long neck?
text: 長い首のせいで、食べ物を飲みこむのにとても時間がかかると思う？

SourceText: She was curious about Rhino. "Why does your horn have a sharp point?"
text: サイについて知りたくなった。「どうして角の先がとがっているの？」

SourceText: A rhino can run about half as fast as a car on a highway.
text: 高速道路を走る車の約半分の速さで、サイは走ることができるよ。

SourceText: A rhino can run three times faster than a person, so don't try to run away from one!
text: サイは人間よりも3倍速く走れるよ。だから、サイから走ってにげようとしないでね！

SourceText: The elephant was curious about the rhino. Are you? What would you like to ask the rhino?
text: ゾウはサイに興味があるね。きみはどうかな？ サイに何を聞いてみたい？

SourceText: She was curious about Hippo. "Why do you have red eyes?" she asked.
text: カバについて知りたくなった。「どうして目が赤いの？」と聞いたよ。

SourceText: Hippos can fill up on grass and then not eat for three weeks! How many days is that? Hint: Skip count by 7's.
text: カバは草でおなかをいっぱいにしてから、3週間食べないでいられるよ！ 3週間は何日分かな？ ヒント: 7とびで数える

SourceText: How long can you go without eating?
text: きみは、どのくらいの間食べないでいられる？

SourceText: Every animal we've seen has a bit of hair at the end of its tail. They are all mammals, and mammals have hair! Even the bowhead whale has hair on its lips, chin, snout, and behind its blowhole.
text: これまで見てきた動物はみんな、しっぽの先に毛があるね。この動物たちはすべてほ乳類だよ。ほ乳類には毛があるね！ ホッキョククジラだって、くちびる、あごや鼻、それからふん気こうの後ろに毛があるよ。

SourceText: And she was VERY curious about Crocodile. "What does Crocodile eat for dinner?" she asked.
text: そして、クロコダイルについてすごく知りたくなった！「クロコダイルは晩ごはんに何を食べるの？」と聞いたよ。

SourceText: How many teeth can you see? If it has the same number of teeth on the other side of its mouth, how many would that be all together?
text: 歯は何本見えるかな？ 口の反対側にも同じ数の歯があるとしたら、みんなでいくつになるかな？

SourceText: What do you think is on his dinner plate under the cover?
text: ふたを取ると、何がお皿の上にのっていると思う？

SourceText: Which is more and which is less: Crocodile's teeth or the bumps on Crocodile's tail?
text: どちらの数が多くて、どちらの数が少ないかな？ クロコダイルの歯、それともしっぽのギザギザ？

SourceText: "Never ask a question like that!" said her mother. Then she walked off, frowning.
text: 「そんなこと聞かないで！」とお母さんは言ったよ。しかめっ面をして、歩いていっちゃった。

SourceText: There are many groups of things in this picture, such as groups of ears, eyes, and eyelashes. How many different groups can you find?
text: この絵では、耳や目、まつ毛などのたくさんの仲間わけができるね。きみは、いくつ違うグループを見つけられるかな？

SourceText: Why did the mother say not to ask such a question?
text: どうしてお母さんはそんな質問をしないでと言ったのかな？

SourceText: Count the eyelashes on both elephants by skip counting by 3's. What would you skip count by to count their feet?
text: 両方のゾウのまつ毛を3とびで数えよう。足はいくつのとび数えで数えたらいいかな？

SourceText: Quickly Crow flew down to baby elephant. "Follow me to the river. There you will see what Crocodile eats for dinner," squawked Crow.
text: すぐにカラスが飛びおりて、「川までついて来て。そうしたら、クロコダイルが晩ごはんに何を食べるかわかるよ。」と鳴いた。

SourceText: Do you think Crow wants to help, or is Crow going to play a trick on Baby Elephant?
text: カラスは赤ちゃんゾウを助けたいのだと思う？ それともだまそうとしているのだと思う？

SourceText: Would you follow Crow?
text: きみならカラスについていく？

SourceText: For each of the numbers from one to four, find a group in this picture with that many things in it.
text: 1つだけのものから4つあるものの中で、どのグループにあてはまるものが1番多いか見てみよう。

SourceText: So the baby elephant followed Crow down to the river.
text: それで、赤ちゃんゾウは川までカラスについていったよ。

SourceText: The yellow path looks narrower in the distance. Things far away often look smaller.
text: 黄色の道は、遠いところではせまくなっているね。遠くはなれたものが小さく見えることはよくあるよ。

SourceText: How would you describe the look on Baby Elephant's face?
text: 赤ちゃんゾウの表情をどんなふうに説明する？

SourceText: Imagine if you had four feet to control to walk like Baby Elephant. Would it be easier or harder than walking on two feet?
text: 赤ちゃんゾウのように4本の足を使って歩くと想像してみて。2本の足で歩くより簡単かな？ それとも難しいかな？

SourceText: She pushed through the reeds and stood on the bank. She looked into the water. Where was Crocodile?
text: 草をおしわけて土手に立った。水の中をのぞきこんだよ。クロコダイルはどこなの？

SourceText: There are the same things on each side of baby elephant. This is called mirror symmetry, or simply symmetry.
text: 赤ちゃんゾウの両横に同じものがあるね。これは鏡面対称、または対称であるというよ。

SourceText: Faces often have mirror symmetry. The flower on baby elephant's face breaks the mirror symmetry of her face.
text: 顔は鏡面対称であることが多いよ。赤ちゃんゾウについている花は、顔の鏡面対称をくずしているね。

SourceText: With mirror symmetry, body parts not on the midline show up in pairs -- for example, two ears, two eyes, and two arms. Because of this, there will be an even number of them.
text: 鏡面対称では、真ん中の線上にないものはペアになっているよ。例えば、2つの耳、2つの目、2本のうでなど。だから、それらは偶数になるね。

SourceText: "Hello," said a stone near the river bank. "Hello," said Baby Elephant. "Can you tell me what Crocodile eats for dinner?" she asked.
text: 「こんにちは」川の土手ちかくの石が言った。「こんにちは」赤ちゃんゾウも言った。「クロコダイルが晩ごはんに何を食べるか教えてくれる？」と聞いたよ。

SourceText: Is Baby Elephant talking to a stone or to Crocodile?
text: 赤ちゃんゾウは石、それともクロコダイルに話しているの？

SourceText: Why is it useful to a crocodile to have its eyes stick up above the water when the rest of its body is below the water?
text: 赤ちゃんゾウは石、それともクロコダイルに話しているの？

SourceText: Count all the circles in this picture. Some parts of some of the circles are blocked from view.
text: この絵の中で、円をすべて数えよう。ある部分が何かで見えなくなっている円もあるね。

SourceText: "Bend down and I will tell you," said the stone. "Lower, lower," said the stone. So Baby Elephant bent down lower, and lower.
text: 「かがんでごらん。そうしたら教えてあげる。」と石が言った。「もっと下だよ、もっと下だよ。」と石が言った。だから赤ちゃんゾウはもっと下にかがんだよ。それからもっともっと下に。

SourceText: Uh oh! Why does Crocodile want Baby Elephant to get closer?
text: おっと、 どうしてクロコダイルは赤ちゃんゾウにもっと近づいて欲しいのかな？

SourceText: What do you think will happen next?
text: あなたは次に何が起こると思いますか？

SourceText: Can the crocodile eat Baby Elephant? Baby Elephant is much bigger than crocodile.
text: クロコダイルは赤ちゃんゾウを食べられるのかな？赤ちゃんゾウはクロコダイルよりももっと大きいよ。

SourceText: Then suddenly, "Snap!" Baby Elephant's nose was caught in Crocodile's jaws. "Crocodile will eat YOU for dinner!" squawked Crow, and flew away.
text: それからとつぜん、「パチン！」とクロコダイルのあごが赤ちゃんゾウの鼻をつかまえた。「クロコダイルは晩ごはんに『きみ』を食べるのさ！」ガーと鳴いて、カラスは飛びさった。

SourceText: Crow tricked Baby Elephant. Can you think of any stories where someone played a trick on someone else?
text: カラスは赤ちゃんゾウをだましたんだね。だれかがだましたお話を何か思いつくかな？

SourceText: Can you think of a time when someone tricked you?
text: だれかにだまされたことはあった？

SourceText: Have you noticed the ground Baby Elephant stands on keeps changing color? Which colors have been used so far?
text: ゾウの下の地面の色が変わっていっていることに気がついた？ これまで何色が使われたのかな？

SourceText: Baby Elephant sat back on her strong legs and pulled. She pulled, and pulled. But Crocodile did not let go of her nose.
text: 赤ちゃんゾウは、強い足ですわって後ろに引っぱった。引っぱって、さらに引っぱった。それでもクロコダイルは鼻をはなさなかった。

SourceText: What is Baby Elephant feeling right now?
text: 赤ちゃんゾウは、今どんな気持ちかな？

SourceText: What is Crocodile feeling right now?
text: クロコダイルは、今どんな気持ちかな？

SourceText: Baby Elephant's nose was described as a shoe in the middle of its face at the start of the story. What does it look like now?
text: お話の始めでは、赤ちゃんゾウの鼻は顔の真ん中にあるくつのようだと表していたね。今はどんなふうに見える？

SourceText: Baby Elephant's nose stretched, and stretched, and stretched. Then, "Thud!" she fell on her back.
text: 赤ちゃんゾウの鼻はのばされて、のばされて、もっとのばされた。それから、「ドスン！」と後ろにたおれた。

SourceText: Have you ever lost your balance and flipped over with a "Thud"?
text: バランスがとれなくなって、「ドスン」とひっくり返ったことはあるかな？

SourceText: Notice the lines that curl and swerve in the picture. What are they telling us?
text: この絵の中の丸い線や曲がりくねった線を見てね。それらは何を伝えているのかな？

SourceText: Point to and count all the extra lines added to the picture.
text: 描き足されたそれらの線を、指でさして数えてみよう。

SourceText: Crocodile sunk back into the water. He was cross about losing his dinner.
text: クロコダイルは水の中にしずんでもどっていった。晩ごはんがなくなって、おこっていたよ。

SourceText: Is this pond big enough for Crocodile, or is it too small?
text: この池の大きさはクロコダイルにちょうどいい？ それとも小さすぎるかな？

SourceText: Is Crocodile's body curled into a ball so that it fits in the pond?
text: クロコダイルの体は、池の中に入れるようにボールみたいに丸くなるのかな？

SourceText: There are three plants near Crocodile. There is another group of three things that shows us how Crocodile is feeling -- where are they?
text: クロコダイルのそばに植物が3つあるね。そのほかに、3つあってクロコダイルの気持ちを表しているものがあるよ。どこにあるのかな？

SourceText: Baby Elephant looked at her nose. It was stretched very long. She could not see where it ended!
text: 赤ちゃんゾウは自分の鼻を見た。とても長くのばされていたよ。どこが終わりなのか見えないくらいだった！

SourceText: How is Baby Elephant feeling about her nose?
text: 赤ちゃんゾウは自分の鼻のことをどう思っているのかな？

SourceText: It can be difficult to accept changes in how you look. Have your looks changed?
text: 見た目が変わるのを受けいれるのは難しいかもしれないね。きみの見た目は変わったことがあるかな？

SourceText: When Baby Elephant stands up, do you think her trunk will touch the ground?
text: 赤ちゃんゾウが立ち上がったら、鼻が地面につくと思う？

SourceText: Her nose was so long she could pick fruit from high branches.
text: 鼻がとっても長くなったから、高い枝からくだものがとれたよ。

SourceText: Her nose has turned into a long trunk. An elephant's trunk has lots of muscles and is very strong.
text: とても長い鼻に変わったね。ゾウの鼻はたくさんの筋肉があってすごく強いんだ。

SourceText: What are some ways that a long trunk is useful? Do you wish you had one?
text: 長い鼻はどんなことに役に立つかな？ きみも長い鼻が欲しかった？

SourceText: Sometimes a change that seemed bad at first turns out to be a good thing. Has something like that happened to you?
text: 最初はよくないと思った変化でも、いい結果になることがあるんだね。きみにもそんなことがあった？

SourceText: Her nose was so long she could shower her back with water. From that day, all elephants have had long and useful trunks.
text: 鼻がとっても長くなったから、背中も水浴びできたよ。この日から、すべてのゾウが長くて便利な鼻をもつようになったんだ。

SourceText: If all elephants have long trunks after this, did each one have to get their nose stretched by a crocodile?
text: もしゾウがみんな長い鼻をもつようになったなら、どのゾウもクロコダイルに鼻を引っぱってもらわないといけなかった？

SourceText: Do you think Baby Elephant should be friends with Crow ever again?
text: 赤ちゃんゾウは、カラスともう一度友達になるべきだと思う？

SourceText: Make up a story like this that explains how the giraffe got such a long neck.
text: このようなお話を作って、キリンの首がどのように長くなったか説明してみよう。

SourceText: Stage 1 Overview

**Overview for Stage 1 playdates**

The Math Learning Step for the introduction for Stage 1 gives an overview of the topics that are covered during this stage. The individual Playdates each have a suggested storybook and some math activities.
Playdate 1-1
**Playdate Focus:** Use Math Talk to point out and describe objects to your child. Talk about the properties of these objects.
This has color words.
These involve the properties of things.
Playdate 1-2
**Playdate Focus:** Continue to use Math Talk to point out and describe objects to your child.
This looks at how clothes can be too big or too small.
These practice shapes and descriptions.
Playdate 1-3
**Playdate Focus:** Describe all the math that is all around you everywhere you go. Use Math Talk to chat about it with your child.
This talks about speed, colors, and small counting.
These involve descriptions of places and objects, and also the following of directions.
Playdate 1-4
**Playdate Focus:** Math is not just counting – math is also about properties and relationships. This should be brought out in your Math Talk.
The storybook talks about colors, shapes, and spatial relationships.
These involve properties of objects and how those properties can create patterns.
Playdate 1-5
**Playdate Focus:** Use counting in your Math Talk. Count everything you come across.
This involves counting and the ideas of one more and one less.
These involve quantities of objects and building with various shapes.
Playdate 1-6
**Playdate Focus:** Your Math Talk changes when your child is able to respond to your comments and questions.
This counts up to 5 and uses relationship words, which you can now use to ask your child about what's going on in the story.
These involve describing things and finding properties that make things similar or different.
Playdate 1-7
**Playdate Focus:** Continue to emphasize words that describe properties and relationships.
This has relative sizes and shapes.
These involve using properties to compare things and find patterns.
Playdate 1-8
**Playdate Focus:** This is centered on what makes objects the same and different.
This has shapes, colors, relationships, and counting up to 5.
These involve grouping things with the same property.
Playdate 1-9
**Playdate Focus:** Use properties of things to establish patterns. Patterns are central to mathematics.
This talks about the daily feeding of hungry animals.
These involve properties and finding patterns involving those properties.
Playdate 1-10
**Playdate Focus:** Discuss basic shapes and emphasize their names and descriptions.
his has shapes on every page.
These continue the ongoing discussions about properties and patterns.
Stage 2 Overview

**Overview for Stage 2 playdates**

The Math Learning Step for the introduction for Stage 2 gives an overview of the topics that are covered during this stage. The individual Playdates each have a suggested storybook and some math activities.
Playdate 2-1
**Playdate Focus:** Count up from 1, start at 0 sometimes. This is the basis of understanding quantities and helps with beginning addition and subtraction.
This has counting from 0 to 9. It also has smallest, biggest, one more, one less, and colors.
One activity introduces the idea of counterexamples. The other activity is a 2-person strategy game making triangles.
Playdate 2-2
**Playdate Focus:** Count down to 1, ending at 0 sometimes. This deepens understanding of the number sequence. It also helps with subtraction.
This has the numbers from 1 to 7. It also has color descriptions on every page.
These involve lots of counting and small quantities. One activity also has adding or subtracting of 1 and 2.
Playdate 2-3
**Playdate Focus:** Understand strategies for comparing small numbers and quantities.
This has counting from 1 to 10; relationship words such as too big or too small; and spatial relationship words such as above and under.
These involve  discovering shapes for quantities and playing with the order of numbers.
Playdate 2-4
**Playdate Focus:** This introduces the idea of Counting On and how valuable it is for understanding quantities and laying a foundation for addition.
These involve the order of numbers and how numbers compare to each other.
Playdate 2-5
**Playdate Focus:** Develop further your child's understanding of shapes. Introduce more shapes and their names and properties. You can use counting now to discuss numbers of edges and corners.
This has lots of shapes on every page.
These involve creating lots of geometric shapes.
Playdate 2-6
**Playdate Focus:** Make a lot of use of "one more" and "one less" to help with the understanding of the number sequence as well as beginning an understanding of addition and subtraction.
This has counting to 9, one more, one less, and many relationship words.
These involve the ordering of numbers and the use of a number line.
Playdate 2-7
**Playdate Focus:** Enjoy adding of small numbers with totals up to 5.
This has counting up to 6, with colors and shapes.
These involve very small counting and adding. For now, only use small sums (up to around 6)  for the Bonded Groups puzzles.
Playdate 2-8
**Playdate Focus:** Fingers are very useful for counting, adding, and subtracting. Show your child how to make good use of their fingers for numbers of 10 or less.
This has counting up to 12, shapes, and comparing.

These involve a number line for counting, adding, and subtracting, and Bonded Groups for practicing adding. Keep the totals for Bonded Groups small (perhaps around 7 or so), and slowly let the totals get larger.
Playdate 2-9
**Playdate Focus:** Have fun skip counting by 2's with your child. It's a fun and fast way to count that helps them see numbers in a new way.
This has skip counting along with shapes and comparisons.
These involve number shapes (to practice pairing things up for skip counting) and making symmetric shapes.
Playdate 2-10
**Playdate Focus:** Playfully find many different ways to count a group of objects. This helps with understanding quantities and that counting, adding, and subtracting can be playful.
This has skip counting and counting up to 14.
These involve putting quantities of things into different shapes as well as playing with making estimates for quantities.
Stage 3 Overview

**Overview for Stage 3 playdates**

The Math Learning Step for the introduction for Stage 3 gives an overview of the topics that are covered during this stage. The individual Playdates each have a suggested storybook and some math activities.
Playdate 3-1
**Playdate Focus:** Practice adding by using the idea of Counting On. The term  Counting On means that, if you count two groups, such as 4 and 3, you start your counting at 4 rather than 1.
This has lots of shapes and groupings of objects.
These involve addition and subtraction. Use the "Numbered" version of Dots and Boxes with small numbers to practice addition.
Playdate 3-2
**Playdate Focus:** Practice subtracting by counting down from the larger number. Talk about how "take away" and "difference" are two good models for subtraction.
This has skip counting, shapes, and comparisons.
These involve comparing, adding, and subtracting.
Playdate 3-3
**Playdate Focus:** Practice subtracting by counting up to find the difference. Reinforce that "take away" and "difference" are two good models for subtraction.
This has counting to 10 and shapes.
These involve addition and some estimating of small quantities.
Playdate 3-4

**Playdate Focus:** The Part-Whole relationship, seeing something as made out of parts, is a significant developmental step for a child. Practice Number Bonds, which are groups of numbers that total to the same result, with your child. Practicing with Ten Frames is an important part of this.
These involve lots of practice with number bonds.
Playdate 3-5

**Playdate Focus:** Ten has a very important role for our numbers. Practice adding and subtracting 10. Also practice taking the numbers from 10 to 19 and breaking them up into 10 plus some ones – for example, that 14 is 10 plus 4 more.
This has lots of shapes and counting with small numbers.
These involve comparing and ordering numbers up to 20.
Playdate 3-6
**Playdate Focus:** Use Fact Families to emphasize the connection between addition and subtraction. This is a natural follow on to the last Playdate's focus on number bonds.
This has counting to 12, colors, shapes, and patterns.
These involve lots of practice with number bonds and with addition and subtraction of small numbers.
Playdate 3-7

**Playdate Focus:** Adding Twins, where you add a number to itself, are often enjoyable addition facts for a child to learn. Near Twins, where you add a number to the next number (such as 3 + 4), are often easy to learn after adding twins have been learned, and they help your child to see how adding facts can be connected.
This has skip counting, adding twins, and counting to 14.
These involve adding practice and estimating using a number line.
Playdate 3-8

**Playdate Focus:** After skip counting by 2's and doing adding twins, it is a great time to start doing doubling, multiplying by 2, halving, dividing by 2, splitting things into two equal parts, and looking at odd and even numbers. This is a lot of topics; however, they go together very naturally.
This has lots of discussion of how to split something fairly among coorperating friends.
These involve doubling and taking halves.
Playdate 3-9

**Playdate Focus:** Do lots of practice skip counting by 2's – do this practice up and down, and start it anywhere (not just at multiples of 2). When this becomes easy, practice with other skip count amounts such as 5 and 10.
These involve practice with addition and subtraction as well as seeing which numbers can be seen as groups of pairs.
Playdate 3-10
**Playdate Focus:** Play lots of strategy games with your child. Even games that don't involve numbers have a lot of math in them. They will develop important problem solving skills.
This has counting to 10, comparisons, and a discussion of problem solving.
These involve lots of problem solving while playing strategy games.
Stage 4 Overview

**Overview for Stage 4 playdates**

The Math Learning Step for the introduction for Stage 4 gives an overview of the topics that are covered during this stage. The individual Playdates each have a suggested storybook and some math activities.
Playdate 4-1
**Playdate Focus:** Count up and down to 100 with your child, paying particular attention to transitions at multiples of 10.
This has lots of shapes, counting, and groupings of objects.
These involve ordering and comparing of numbers. Use numbers to 100 for I'm Thinking of a Number.
Playdate 4-2

**Playdate Focus:** Use Expanded Form and 2-digit place value to understand the value and meaning of numbers. Expanded Form is breaking a number into tens and ones, such as 43 is 40 + 3. Place value is understanding that 43 means 4 tens and 3 ones – the place a digit is in is what gives it its value. Use Expanded Form and place value to help compare numbers.
This has counting to 20, descriptions, and shapes.
These involve ordering and comparing games.
Playdate 4-3
**Playdate Focus:** Use fingers and Counting On to make it easy to add a single-digit number to any number. Use Compensation to make some addition problems much easier.
This has shapes, quantities, and speeds.
These involve lots of addition and subtraction, and some practice with number bonds.
Playdate 4-4
**Playdate Focus:** Use fingers to make it easy to subtract a single-digit number from any number, or to subtract any two numbers whose difference is a single-digit number.
This has lots of shapes and polygons (many-sided flat shapes).
These involve lots of practice with addition and subtraction.
Playdate 4-5
**Playdate Focus:** Use compensation to make adding and subtracting a lot easier.
This has counting of groups and lots of comparison words.
These involve adding and subtracting, as well as a little bit of probability.
Playdate 4-6
**Playdate Focus:** Use 10 as an intermediate stop to make mental arithmetic for adding and subtracting a lot easier, as well as reinforcing number relationships.
This has skip counting and number properties.
These involve adding, subtracting, and number bonds.
Playdate 4-7

**Playdate Focus:** Practice skip counting by 2's, 5's, and 10's starting anywhere and going up and down. This helps a lot with addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. Skip counting by 10's also helps with place value.
This has counting to 14 and skip counting.
These involve place value and simple additions with two-digit numbers.
Playdate 4-8
**Playdate Focus:** Use doubling and halving as a way to start using the words of multiplication and division without making a big deal about it.
This has skip counting and shapes.
These involve doubling, adding or subtracting single-digit numbers with double-digit numbers, and place value.
Playdate 4-9
**Playdate Focus:** Do mental multiplication with your child for any two numbers from 1 to 5. This is the beginning of mastering multiplication!
This has skip counting, shapes, and colors.

These involve addition, subtraction, and multiplication. Number Scramble can now involve all three of these operations. War using multiplication should only use the cards from 1 to 5 until your child is comfortable with larger numbers.
Playdate 4-10

**Playdate Focus:** This is a chance to take a deeper look at problem solving using strategy games. A strategy game is any game where the players have choices that can make the outcome of the game better or worse.
This has counting, comparisons, and problem solving.
These involve addition and subtraction. Use the numbered version of Dots and Boxes and write in two-digit numbers if your child is ready for them.
Stage 5 Overview

**Overview for Stage 5 playdates**

The Math Learning Step for the introduction for Stage 5 gives an overview of the topics that are covered during this stage. The individual Playdates each have some suggested math activities.
Playdate 5-1
**Playdate Focus:** Your child's numbers are going above 100, and their adding and subtracting involves two-digit numbers. Practice 2-digit and 3-digit expanded form and place value with them.
Playdate 5-2
**Playdate Focus:** Use expanded form to practice double-digit addition and subtraction.
These involve two-digit addition and subtraction.
Playdate 5-3
**Playdate Focus:** Practice skip counting up and down by any skip amount starting at any number (not just multiples). This skip counting is great practice for all four of the operations.
These involve lots of practice with skip counting.
Playdate 5-4
**Playdate Focus:** Practice mental multiplication using doubling for 2, 4, and 8. Practice mental multiplication by 5 and 10 because they are useful and easy.
These involve doubling and general multiplication practice.
Playdate 5-5
**Playdate Focus:** Use the idea of one more and one less to practice mental multiplication for multiplying by 3, 4, 6, 9, and 11. For example, multiplying by 6 is one more than multiplying by 5.
These involve lots of multiplication practice along with some mixed operation practice.
Playdate 5-6
**Playdate Focus:** All the pieces are in place, and your child is ready to finish off the mastery of all single-digit multiplication!
These are repeated from the last Playdate and involve lots of multiplication practice along with some mixed operation practice.
Playdate 5-7

**Playdate Focus:** Now that your child is getting comfortable with multiplying and dividing, it's time to develop a sense of how numbers can evenly divide other numbers. This involves in learning and practice the words: factor, divisor, and multiple.
These involve lots of practice with factors and multiples.
Playdate 5-8

**Playdate Focus:** Using multiplication, primes are the building blocks of numbers. Help your child develop a strong sense of prime factorizations. The new words for this Playdate are: prime, composite, unit, and power.
These involve lots of practice with multiplication and divisibility playing with Turning the Tables. Practice prime factorizations by using them when you play Beep.
Playdate 5-9
**Playdate Focus:** Practicing with fact families is a good way to deepen your child's understanding of the interconnection between multiplication and division.
These involve lots of practice with multiplication and divisibility playing with Turning the Tables. Practice multiples by using them when you play Beep.
Playdate 5-10
**Playdate Focus:** This is a quick first step at practicing division with and without remainders.
These involve lots of practice with multiplication and division.

SourceText: Math Learning Steps
text: 数学学習ステップ

SourceText: Playdates
text: プレイデート

SourceText:
First and foremost, playing math games should be fun, like any other game your family plays together!

Please let your child make poor plays (mistakes) without correction, and resist the urge to tell them the best ways to play. Bit by bit, your child will get better at the game, and they will learn so much more if you let them figure things out. There is no hurry.

If you see your child make a mistake, ask them to describe why they decided to do what they did. If your child is stuck and doesn't know which play to make, ask them to describe the pros and cons of their choices, or ask them about how they solved a similar situation in the past. If your child doesn't remember how to do a calculation, discuss with them the methods they know for figuring it out. These conversations are important for helping your child to develop mathematically. 

Through math game play and math conversations, you are helping your child learn to enjoy math and develop important problem solving skills!
text:
まず第一に、数学ゲームを遊ぶことは、家族で一緒に遊ぶ他のゲームと同じように 楽しい ものであるべきです。

お子さんがうまくいかないプレイ（間違い）をしても、すぐに訂正せずに見守ってください。また、つい「こうした方がいい」と教えたくなる気持ちを抑えてください。少しずつ、お子さんはゲームが上手になり、自分で考えながら学ぶことで、より多くのことを身につけることができます。焦る必要はありません。

もしお子さんが間違いをした場合は、なぜその行動を選んだのか説明してもらいましょう。お子さんが行動に迷っている場合は、それぞれの選択肢の メリット・デメリット を話し合ったり、過去に似た状況でどのように解決したかを聞いてみたりしてください。計算方法が思い出せない場合は、どのようにして答えを導き出せるか、お子さんの知っている方法を一緒に話し合いましょう。こうした会話は、お子さんが数学的に考える力を育てるうえでとても大切です。

数学ゲームで遊び、こうした数学の会話を重ねることで、お子さんは 数学を楽しむ力 と 重要な問題解決能力 を身につけることができます。

SourceText:
Puzzles are meant to be challenging and to take time, so please don't ruin the fun by telling your child how to do them. These puzzles are chosen so that you can create them easily and then have fun solving them together.

If your child gets stuck on a puzzle, you have several options. You can, of course, give very small hints, if you can think of things that won't give away the puzzle. You can suggest looking at smaller or simpler versions of the puzzle. Encourage your child to be bold in their ideas, even if sometimes they lead to dead ends. We all learn a lot from our mistakes and dead ends! Let your child know that it is perfectly okay not to solve a puzzle on the first (or second or third) try, and that useful ideas may occur to them if they leave the puzzle alone for a day or two.

These puzzles are meant to be fun and to teach problem solving. One of the greatest mathematical pleasures is that AHA moment, after many false starts and much wrestling with a problem, when the answer is finally discovered – be sure to let your child experience that feeling of discovery as many times as you can!
text:
パズルは挑戦することを目的としており、時間をかけて取り組むものです。ですので、お子さんに解き方を教えてしまうと楽しさが損なわれてしまいます。これらのパズルは、簡単に作れて、家族で一緒に楽しみながら解けるように選ばれています。

もしお子さんがパズルで行き詰まった場合、いくつかの対応方法があります。もちろん、パズルの答えを直接教えない程度の 小さなヒント を出すこともできます。また、より小さく簡単なバージョンのパズルを試してみるように提案することもできます。たとえ行き止まりに至ったとしても、お子さんのアイデアを 大胆に試すことを励ます ことが大切です。私たちは、失敗や行き止まりからも多くのことを学びます。

お子さんに、パズルを最初の挑戦（あるいは二回目や三回目）で解けなくても まったく問題ない と伝えましょう。また、パズルを一日か二日置いておくことで、思いもよらない役立つアイデアが浮かぶこともあります。

これらのパズルは 楽しむこと と 問題解決の力を育てること を目的としています。数学の最大の喜びのひとつは、多くの試行錯誤を経たあと、ついに答えを見つけたときの 「あっ！」というひらめきの瞬間 です。お子さんがその発見の喜びをできるだけ多く経験できるようにしましょう。

SourceText:
Investigations are meant for your child to play with and think about. Let your child explore these looking for interesting patterns and beautiful relationships. Resist the temptation to unveil what is going on and give the answer. If your child seems to have reached a dead end, suggest that they come back to the investigation at a future time to play with it again.

Many investigations benefit from organizing results, and this is a great thing for you to help your child with. Help them make tables, drawings, or whatever may help them see more easily what is going on. And of course, it is perfectly fine to give them gentle nudges from time to time in the right direction. Remember that your child will learn a lot by developing persistence and learning how to look more deeply at things.
text:
調べ学習は、お子さんが 遊びながら考える ことを目的としています。お子さんが興味深いパターンや美しい関係性を見つけられるよう、自由に探究させてあげてください。つい答えを教えたくなる気持ちはぐっと我慢しましょう。もしお子さんが行き詰まっているようであれば、後でまた挑戦して遊ぶように提案しても構いません。

多くの調べ学習では、結果を整理することで理解が深まります。ここで親が手助けしてあげるのはとても良いことです。表や図、その他見やすくするための方法を一緒に作ってあげましょう。また、もちろん時々 やさしく方向を示す助言 をすることも大丈夫です。

お子さんは、粘り強さを身につけたり、物事を深く観察する力 を養うことで、多くのことを学びます。

SourceText: Helping your child
text: お子さんをサポートする

SourceText: Before Talking
text: 発語の前段階

SourceText: Talk with your child before they can talk or even understand the words. Point at, name, and describe things you see, such as shapes, colors, comparisons, and quantities. As your child begins to understand words, ask about a thing and have your child point at it. For example, "Where is the ball?" If your child can't find the thing, point to it for them.
text: お子さんが言葉を話したり理解できたりするようになる前から、形、色、比較や量など、目に見えるものを指差し、名前を付けて説明するなどして話しかけましょう。お子さんが言葉を理解し始めたら、たとえば「ボールはどこ？」というように、ある物について尋ね、お子さんに指差しさせてみましょう。もしお子さんが見つけられない場合は代わりに指差してあげてください。

SourceText: Early Talking
text: 発語初期

SourceText: As your child begins to understand and say words, mix in simple questions. Freely help with answers as needed. If you point and say "Is this red?" and they don't know, supply the answer. If you say "Count the blocks." and your child does not know how, point and count the blocks with them "one, two, three."
text: お子さんが言葉を理解し、話し始めたら、簡単な質問を混ぜてください。必要に応じて自由に答えを手助けしてあげてください。たとえばあなたが指差して「これは赤？」と聞いてもお子さんがわからない場合は、答えを教えてあげます。また、「ブロックを数えて」と指示してもお子さんがどのようにするのかわからなかったら、指差しながら「いち、に、さん…」と一緒に数えてあげてください。

SourceText: 3 Levels of Discussion
text: ３つのレベル

SourceText:
Pick an appropriate level for your child. Allow time for thought when asking questions or making comments. Help with the answer when your child stumbles, and follow up correct answers with questions or comments that are small expansions on the child's answer. 

**Level 1** Ask simple direct questions. Ask and point at what you see on the page. Where is the toy? What are they doing? What is its name? What color is it? How many balls are there? 
**Level 2** Ask general or open questions about this point in the story. What do you see happening here? What is this group of things? 
**Level 3** Ask about the story line. What has happened? What will happen next? Have you had experiences or seen things similar to this? How does she feel when this happens?
text:
お子さんに合ったレベルを選びましょう。質問やコメントをする時には考える時間を与えましょう。お子さんが答えに詰まった時は手助けをし、正しい答えには少し膨らませた質問やコメントをしてみましょう。

**レベル1** 簡単で直接的な質問をします。見えるものについて尋ねたり指をさしたりしましょう。おもちゃはどこかな？何をしているのかな？その名前は何かな？色は何かな？いくつボールがあるかな？
**レベル2** お話のある部分について一般的な質問または自由に答えられる質問をしてみましょう。ここで何が起こっていると思う？この物の仲間は何かな？
**レベル3** お話の筋について質問をしてみましょう。何が起こったのかな？次はどうなるかな？これと似たようなことが前にあったかな？この時、この子はどう感じているかな？

SourceText: Read, Talk, and Have Fun!
text: 楽しく読んで話しましょう！

SourceText:
The supplied questions and comments are just the beginning. 

1. For the first reading, read the red questions and comments. 
2. For the second reading, read the blue questions and comments. 
3. For the third reading, read the green questions and comments. 

After that, follow your child's interests and let your discussions go in fun directions.
text:
書かれている質問やコメントはほんの一例に過ぎません。

１回目は赤の質問とコメントを読みます。
２回目は青の質問とコメントを読みます。
３回目は緑の質問とコメントを読みます。

その後はお子さんの興味に合わせて、楽しい方向に話を進めてください。

SourceText: Activities – Bonus Material
text: アクティビティ – ボーナス教材

SourceText: Stage
text: ステージ

SourceText: Language
text: 言語

SourceText: Continue

Each Stage has ten playdates for your family to enjoy with a group of other families. Each playdate has suggested storybooks and activities to enjoy together during the playdate. The playdates correspond to the ten math learning steps for each Stage. Links are provided to give direct and easy access to each of those resources.
text: 各ステージの名前は、そのステージを始めるためにお子さんに必要な主なスキルを表しています。例えば、お子さんが10まで数えられ、その数字の意味を理解している場合は ステージ 3 から始めます。ステージの教材は 学習の進行順 に設計されており、後のセクションは前の内容に基づいて構成されています。

SourceText: Each Stage of learning is divided into ten basic learning steps. Each step describes what your child is learning, how you can help with that learning, and how the steps are connected with each other.
text: 各ステージの学習は 10の基本学習ステップ に分かれています。各ステップには、お子さんが何を学んでいるか、どのようにサポートできるか、そしてステップ同士のつながりが説明されています。

SourceText: Each of the Stages has about a dozen sections of fun games, puzzles, activities, and investigations for your family to enjoy together.
text: 各ステージには、家族で一緒に楽しめる ゲーム、パズル、アクティビティ、調べ学習 がそれぞれ約12セクションずつ含まれています。

SourceText: Stages
text: ステージ

SourceText: Each Stage name describes the main requirement for your child to start that Stage. For example, if your child can count to ten, and knows what those numbers mean, then start with Stage 3. The materials in the Stages are designed in a learning progression so that later sections build on the earlier ones.
text: 各ステージの名前は、そのステージを始めるためにお子さんに必要な主なスキルを表しています。例えば、お子さんが10まで数えられ、その数字の意味を理解している場合は ステージ 3 から始めます。ステージの教材は 学習の進行順 に設計されており、後のセクションは前の内容に基づいて構成されています。

SourceText: Please select the kinds of activities you would like to do.
text: 行いたいアクティビティの種類を選んでください。

SourceText: Please select whether you would rather view the Stage activities individually or by topic.
text: ステージのアクティビティを個別に見るか、テーマ別に見るか選んでください。

SourceText: Reading with your child is a wonderful experience! These storybooks are for an adult to read to a child. Adding math comments and questions to your reading helps your child grow mathematically, and creates strong associations of math with this happy, cozy experience.
text: お子さんと一緒に読むことは素晴らしい体験です！これらのストーリーブックは、大人が子どもに読み聞かせるためのものです。読みながら数学に関するコメントや質問を加えることで、お子さんの 数学的な成長 を助け、楽しい読書体験と数学を結びつけることができます。

SourceText: Please select the kinds of stories you would like to choose from.
text: 読みたいストーリーの種類を選んでください。

SourceText: Beginning Storybooks
text: 初級ストーリーブック

SourceText: Talk with your child before they can talk or even understand the words. Point at, name, and describe things you see, such as shapes, colors, comparisons, and quantities. As your child begins to understand words, ask about a thing and have your child point at it. As your child begins to understand and say words, mix in simple questions.
text: まだ言葉を話せない、理解できないお子さんに向けて、形や色、比較や数量など目に見えるものを指さしながら名前を教えたり説明したりします。言葉を理解し始めたら指さしで答えさせ、話せるようになったら簡単な質問を交えてみましょう。

SourceText: Intermediate Storybooks
text: 中級ストーリーブック

SourceText: These storybooks are somewhat longer, have slightly more complex story lines, and involve more sophisticated ideas. Your child is now able to talk and reason about more things in the world.
text: 少し長めで、少し複雑なストーリーや考えさせる内容が含まれています。お子さんは、世界のさまざまな事柄について話したり考えたりできるようになっています。

SourceText: Advanced Storybooks
text: 上級ストーリーブック

SourceText: The story lines are getting ever more detailed and complex. The math involves larger numbers and more advanced concepts. The description of objects is getting more detailed and involved.
text: ストーリーはますます詳細で複雑になります。数学も大きな数字やより高度な概念を含み、物の描写もより詳しくなります。

SourceText: Bonus Material
text: ボーナス教材

SourceText: Some of the activities have additional material with examples and further explanations. You can look at them here or at the end of the corresponding activity page.
text: いくつかのアクティビティには、例やさらに詳しい説明を含むボーナス教材があります。これらは、対応するアクティビティページの最後やこちらのリンクから見ることができます。

SourceText: Welcome!
text: ようこそ！

SourceText: Enjoy reading and playing with math together! The best way to learn and experience math is in a social and playful way. Early Family Math has created four kinds of materials for your family to enjoy together.
text: 一緒に数学を読み、遊びながら楽しみましょう！数学を学び、体験する最良の方法は、社会的で遊びのある方法 です。Early Family Math では、家族で楽しめる4種類の教材を作成しました。

SourceText: Storybooks
text: ストーリーブック

SourceText: These storybooks are for an adult to read to a child. They have math comments and guiding questions on every page. Help your child grow mathematically and create strong associations of math with the happy, cozy experience of reading together!
text: 大人が子どもに読み聞かせるストーリーブックです。ページごとに数学に関するコメントや質問があり、楽しい読書体験と数学を結びつけます。

SourceText: Activities
text: アクティビティ

SourceText: These educationally sequenced math games, puzzles, activities, and investigations, designed for your family to play together, provide lots of enjoyable family time as your child learns all the math they need for school.
text: 家族で一緒に遊べる順序立てられた数学ゲーム、パズル、アクティビティ、調べ学習です。楽しい時間を過ごしながら、お子さんは学校で必要な数学を学べます。

SourceText: Math Learning Steps
text: 数学学習ステップ

SourceText: Have you ever wondered what the beginning learning steps are for math, and how they connect with each other? Here are brief descriptions of the ten math learning steps your child will be experiencing as they go through each of the five Stages.
text: 数学の学習を始めるステップはどのように構成されているか、ステップ同士はどのようにつながっているか知っていますか？ここでは、各ステージでお子さんが体験する10の数学学習ステップを簡単に紹介します。

SourceText: Playdates
text: プレイデート

SourceText: Get together with other families and have a math playdate. These playdates have suggested storybooks, games, and puzzles for your group of families to enjoy together.
text: 他の家族と集まって数学のプレイデートを楽しみましょう。おすすめのストーリーブック、ゲーム、パズルが提案されており、グループで楽しめます。

SourceText: Help
text: ヘルプ

SourceText: If you ever want to see this introduction again, just click on the question mark.
text: この導入を再度読みたい場合は、はてなマークをクリックしてください。
